Windows to run their Point of Sales software so what can you do about all
this well the first step is really to reduce your exposure and I think one of the best
ways to do that is to really understand that your sensitive information that you
process that you store is an asset and it's a liability and if you don't
absolutely 100% need it to do your business to do whatever it is that your core is your core business function you
need to get rid of it and although it's not strictly in the point of sale realm
but there are systems uh for example if you take payments online uh you can use
apis and integration points from PayPal and services like strike to at least off
Lo for example the processing of credit card information to a third party and
this is uh this is key because then you don't have to worry about how to secure
the information that you saved it's saved somewhere else and you can focus on what you're trying to do in this case
if you're in a in a retail or you're generating Revenue you can focus on the sales and not about compliance around
how to protect all that information you collect and and this is uh something I
raised on an interview this week about the University of Maryland data breach uh again they were they've been using

in today's climate I think it's also important to really have a really good understanding
of where your sensitive data goes where is it processed where is it stored what it touches even to the point of really
mapping out all the different systems all the different types of information sensitive data that you have um and

why things are getting lost in compliance because when things get this complex we have to focus on the basics

at the point of capture so this recommendation along with something like chip and pin eliminates the problem of

hitting vulnerable or soft targets like Windows 98
and I think again really focusing on and acknowledging that organizations we just
